content.description:
Bouldery climb, good holds but pumpy and sustained.



Far right side of Duckland. Accessed by hiking up to the right and to the top of a large block, from where the climbing beings.

Bolted and bolted anchor

"Ah, it's duke" 
 "Duck I says." 
  
 A well varied route on the left end of the sector.  Work your way through the strange dike feature, then trend right.  The corner is fun and offers a few options, then pull the roof (bat hang!) and continue easily to the chains.   
 Certainly try and not embarrass yourself- you are on display...

Left end of Duckland, starts in a dike-like feature with a low first bolt.
10 bolts

Enjoyable move with some other nice bits of climbing.  Begin near the muck with some balancy moves to the two edges situated below the roof and catapult yourself to the hold above the lip.  There are two more sections of engaging climbing above, the shark fin bit being quite enjoyable.

Above the puddle, easily identified by the eyebolt hanger above the roof.
Half dozen bolts or so.  Lowering twice aids in janitorial duties.

Climb nice dark rock with good holds and feet.



Farthest left route at Duckland. Accessed by crossing marshy ground to far left

Bolted and bolted anchor

This route climbs up good holds that quickly turn slopey and small right when you need them to clip. They soon after get much larger and ends with fun chill climbing.

Just right of Nobody's Girl.
5 bolts to anchors.

Begin just right of the pool and the more difficult routes in the alcove.  Benign blocky moves lead to a strenuous bulge which ends with a tough clip.  Execute a final move and mantel to easier climbing leading into a small corner and the chains.

6 or so bolts

A great warm up and excuse to plug some gear. Climb the obvious roofy corner that trends left and merges with the finish for Howard the Duck. Solid but thoughtful gear.



The obvious roofy corner that trends left and merges with the finish for Howard the Duck. Start on blocks where the corner begins.

Standard rack.

Easy climbing brings you to a high clip for a high first bolt (long draw). Pull over the first lip to gain a stance under the roof. Clip the bolt in the roof (long draw, really hard to see from the ground), before getting completely turbo-boxed while you try to traverse left. Gain a decent stance just left of the roof to recover. 

Cruise up and left to link/finish on "Dynomite." It's not hard, but it would be quite easy to pump out. There is a sport run-out to the chains. The route is adequately protected, but a fall from the chains would be nasty. 

Long draw bolts 1/2 and 4/5. To clean, thread your rope through the quick links on bolts 2 and 4... your rope is still going to get wet. 



There are a pair of massive roof features, the low roof is staggered to the right. Look for the bolt above the pillar at the back of the low roof, this is your line (traverses left). 

8 bolts, fixed anchor (bring a bonus draw for the anchor)

One of the farthest areas from the end of the Lake Duckland has a number of routes the majority of which are in the harder (11a - 12a) range.   Easily recognized by the large overhang in the middle of the buttress (formed at the prow). 
  
 The climbs here suffer from seepage from above and can take a while to dry our completely after rain.
